name: Vadim Dovganyuk
description: Ukrainian-born Karaite. Translator. Boxer. Adoptee. Social worker. Father to 4 amazing autistic children. Young ambassador @childaidrr. 🇵🇱🇺🇦✡️☮️🕊️
tweet: @monerief @_tarawinkler We are still talking about tens of thousands of children who can't. And with foster care not having enough resources, we still have a need of orphanages. After all, we don't want them on the streets, do we?

name: Vadim Dovganyuk
description: Ukrainian-born Karaite. Translator. Boxer. Adoptee. Social worker. Father to 4 amazing autistic children. Young ambassador @childaidrr. 🇵🇱🇺🇦✡️☮️🕊️
tweet: @monerief @_tarawinkler Honestly, not wanting more children in orphanages is understandable. And, yes, helping children who can stay with their parents to actually stay with their parents is a great start. But it shouldn't go at the cost of the care of those who can't.

name: Vadim Dovganyuk
description: Ukrainian-born Karaite. Translator. Boxer. Adoptee. Social worker. Father to 4 amazing autistic children. Young ambassador @childaidrr. 🇵🇱🇺🇦✡️☮️🕊️
tweet: @monerief @_tarawinkler There is no 1 solution. Especially as we are missing resources in every regard. We are lacking adoptive parents. We are lacking foster parents. And we are lacking employed caregivers. If we are going to push 1 way, it will cause disadvantages for the children.

name: Vadim Dovganyuk
description: Ukrainian-born Karaite. Translator. Boxer. Adoptee. Social worker. Father to 4 amazing autistic children. Young ambassador @childaidrr. 🇵🇱🇺🇦✡️☮️🕊️
tweet: @monerief @_tarawinkler Regardless, you're both missing the most important thing, which is that it's all about the child. Every child is different, and different things will work for each of them. Some will have benefit of foster care, others of adoption, and even those of children's homes.

name: Vadim Dovganyuk

tweet: @alithialithia I understand what you mean, and I agree with you. I personally prefer regular life over the "internet life" most people have today. Though, I have to admit, I'm not very open about my feelings either. However, that is in my case not because of computers and gadgets.

name: Vadim Dovganyuk

name: Vadim Dovganyuk
description: Ukrainian-born Karaite. Translator. Boxer. Adoptee. Social worker. Father to 4 amazing autistic children. Young ambassador @childaidrr. 🇵🇱🇺🇦✡️☮️🕊️
tweet: @monerief @escalante_pete @ScionOfScorpio @mrsgreen99 @VanillaSkyTess The thing is, there are those special parents who don't do it for some kind of "bragging right", who truly do it for the child, but they are basically a needle in a haystack. name: Vadim Dovganyuk

tweet:
As a side note, as many people seem to be unaware of it:
The terms "resident", "citizen", and "national" can't be interchanged, they don't mean the same. 😐

In simplicity:
Nationality - where you're born.
Residency - where you live.
Citizenship - where you are registered. https://t.co/L6jWc834Nm

name: Vadim Dovganyuk
description: Ukrainian-born Karaite. Translator. Boxer. Adoptee. Social worker. Father to 4 amazing autistic children. Young ambassador @childaidrr. 🇵🇱🇺🇦✡️☮️🕊️
tweet: ➡️ Yet, like the separatists in the East of our country, you choose where you live yourself. You can always move to a place that is better, it is a choice. And when it comes to antisemitism, there are only 2 countries I would prefer over Ukraine, the Netherlands & Israel. ➡️

name: Vadim Dovganyuk

name: Vadim Dovganyuk
description: Ukrainian-born Karaite. Translator. Boxer. Adoptee. Social worker. Father to 4 amazing autistic children. Young ambassador @childaidrr. 🇵🇱🇺🇦✡️☮️🕊️
tweet:
it is the only way I know that works while not having to be busy for 48+ hours checking my following lists once a month...
I hope this explains it all to you.

And to @TwitterSupport, would it be possible to make the follows to stay visible on locked accounts?

cc @eirliani

name: Vadim Dovganyuk
description: Ukrainian-born Karaite. Translator. Boxer. Adoptee. Social worker. Father to 4 amazing autistic children. Young ambassador @childaidrr. 🇵🇱🇺🇦✡️☮️🕊️
tweet:
Because of that you may be unfollowed because of the fact your account is locked. If that's the case, you could always send me a message, and I will follow again.
It's sad it has to be this way, but until #Twitter will dedicate more time on preventing follow baiting (cont)

name: Vadim Dovganyuk
description: Ukrainian-born Karaite. Translator. Boxer. Adoptee. Social worker. Father to 4 amazing autistic children. Young ambassador @childaidrr. 🇵🇱🇺🇦✡️☮️🕊️
tweet:
During the unfollowing, there's only looked at the fact if you're still following if not, you're unfollowed. Simple and easy.
However, if your account is locked for any reason, your follows become invisible, and to others it seems like you are no longer following them. (cont)

name: Vadim Dovganyuk
description: Ukrainian-born Karaite. Translator. Boxer. Adoptee. Social worker. Father to 4 amazing autistic children. Young ambassador @childaidrr. 🇵🇱🇺🇦✡️☮️🕊️
tweet:

Only when an account gets locked too often it will get suspended, because in that case it's classified as bot.
Hence bot-like accounts don't get suspended when they are not active, as their account was not locked enough times, and it neither did anything illegal. (2/2)

.@globalvoices You might want to educate yourself on the difference between a suspension and an account lock.

Suspension: A (most often) permanent ban because of illegal activity.
Lock: A temporarily inability to access an account because of irregular activity.

tweet: Which is where the second P comes into play, as with photos someone could trace a more accurate location. A dead end in my case, but not in all cases. Your surroundings could cause you troubles, as could a logo of some company. The problems tend to be the small things.

When to use "The" in front of a country name?

@loveGoldenHeart @BettySaundraWa @RobertLengete85 It's an institutionalized system here with a lack of social workers. Where I used to live, it was 1 social worker every 26 children... So, it rather was the other way around.

name: Vadim Dovganyuk

And I have to admit that I used to be one who chose homelessness over getting helped by the state.
